question: Should the Muslim veil be banned?

content.source_1: European Court of Human Rights, S.A.S. v. France (2014) — The Court upheld France’s nationwide ban on full-face coverings in public, accepting “living together” as a legitimate aim and finding the measure proportionate within the state’s margin of appreciation.
content.source_2: UN Human Rights Committee, Views in Yaker v. France and Hebbadj v. France (2018) — The Committee found France’s face-veil ban violated the ICCPR (Articles 18 and 26), judging it a disproportionate restriction on freedom of religion that disproportionately targets Muslim women.
content.source_3: Open Society Foundations, “Unveiling the Truth: Why 32 Muslim Women Wear the Full-face Veil” (2011) — Qualitative interviews across several European countries reported that many women choose the niqab for personal or religious reasons and that bans increase harassment, social isolation, and withdrawal from public life.
content.source_4: Pew Research Center, “Widespread Support for Bans on Full Islamic Veil in Western Europe” (2010) — Cross-national polling found majorities in several Western European countries favored banning the full-face veil in public, indicating strong public backing for such policies in some contexts.
content.source_5: BBC News, “France to ban full-face veils” (2010) — Reporting cited France’s Interior Ministry estimate that roughly 1,900 women wore the full-face veil nationwide at the time, a figure used by critics to question the proportionality of a blanket ban affecting a very small group.
content.source_6: The Guardian, coverage of French feminist Elisabeth Badinter on the burqa/niqab (2010) — Prominent feminist arguments in favor of bans framed the full-face veil as a symbol of female subordination incompatible with gender equality and secular public space, supporting prohibition on egalitarian grounds.
